results.title: Convoy of life
results.creator_credit: Doss Jenkins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Doss Jenkins’ driving instructor was not fond of female drivers and was strict but she passed and soon became part of a long convoy transporting American goods over Australia. The journey was a gruelling and hot 108 weeks on the road, travelling at 50km an hour. Doss reflects on the things that kept her going, the games she played and the friends she made. This group of ladies still have an annual reunion due to the strong bond created by the journey.

results.title: Convicted
results.creator_credit: Kay Pavlou, Mike Piper and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: 5% of prisoners in Australian prisons are women. 85% of these are in prison for drug-related crimes. In this film the women of Northfield Prison Complex in South Australia, prisoners, warders, psychologists, recount their experiences. The specific problems of women - the care of children, familial attitudes, low self-esteem are highlighted as is the lack of rehabilitation which leads to 65% recidivism.

results.title: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Geoff Burton, John Izzard, Seedwillow and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Alan Wearne, poet and tutor hosts this documentary about his friend and colleague John Forbes (1950-98), one of Australia’s most prominent modern poets with his distinctly gritty writing about urban Melbourne and Sydney. Drawing on extracts from several of Forbes’ poems, and discussions with friends and devotees of his writing, the following works are explored in detail: “Tropical skiing”; “On the beach”; “Stalin’s holidays”; “The Stunned mullet”; “Damaged glamour”.
results.title_for_label: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]

results.title: Conversation in the garden
results.creator_credit: Richard Mudford and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A couple are seen in a suburban garden; outwardly they appear polite, inwardly their thoughts vividly snake through the undergrowth. Cast includes Heather Bolton and Stephen Clements.

results.title: Convention of Yanmar Overseas Agents, 1964
results.brief_description:
Convention held in Japan for overseas agents of the company Yanmar, founded by Magokichi Yamaoka. Shows the delegates involved in various activities including a visit to the factory, a bus trip to a memorial for the founder, group conference and discussion, social evening event, presentation of awards, a golf day, and the final gathering before departure.
Silent film - no credits available.

results.title: Controversy over the moon
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Presents the controversy concerning the geological make-up of the moon - specifically the origin of large lunar craters. Two eminent scientists interpret the same available data and discuss reasons for their divergent views. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Controlling quality is everybody's business
results.creator_credit: Wallace J. Richardson and Industrial Education Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the need for a sound working knowledge of the principles of effective quality control, and how these may be applied. The film also dramatises the importance of maintaining good quality, and shows how everyone can help.

results.title: Controlled photographic lighting
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the three basic considerations in controlled photographic lighting: placement of lights, quality of light and lighting ratio. Shows the functions of main, fill, background and accent lights.

results.title: Controlled heat
results.creator_credit: Jack Chambers, Douglas Clarke and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: By means of diagrams and photography tells the story of thermostatic control. Shows, in fact, how the expansion of metals when heated can be used to regulate temperatures. The story is treated historically, beginning in the 18th century with the problem of accurate time-keeping, especially for navigation, and leading up to such complicated modern examples as open-hearth steel processing.
